title.narrative: STITCH-Global system change

description.narrative: As the Sustainable Textile Initiative: Together for Change (STITCH) consortium, we envision a global garment industry that contributes to an equal and just society by respecting human rights in the world of work. The global garment industry is fragmented and complex, involving many actors across the globe, with varying levels of power and influence. This activity relates to the work contributing to the global industry change.

title.narrative: Local partners and STITCH form coalitions with allies (e.g.: global unions, ILO, OECD, Dutch embassies) to drive lobby and advocacy efforts for “the new normal’’ in the global garment industry
Number of common positions and joint statements submitted for policies, laws or guiding principles on main Lobby and Advocacy goals/strategies

description.narrative: Any formal joint statements or common positions shared by STITCH with outside stakeholders as part of lobby and advocacy efforts. This is a joint activity indicator (with contributions from multiple STITCH partners), and is only reported by this STITCH partner to avoid double counting

comment.narrative: At the time of baseline, at European level, only a small number of countries had adopted policies including HRDD legislation, inclusion of decent work clauses in trade agreements and IRBC agreements.
Includes common positions and joint statements issued on HRDD legislation, inclusion of decent work clauses in trade agreements and IRBC agreements, DE mHRDD, EU mHRDD etc.

title.narrative: Increased collaboration
Number of influencing activities held with policymakers, companies, influential decision-makers on key STITCH Lobby and Advocacy goals/strategies

description.narrative: Influencing activities include dialogues, meetings, consultations, briefings, seminars, workshops, conferences, summits, etc. held with policymakers, companies, influential decision-makers on main STITCH issues, claims and policy goals

comment.narrative: At the time of baseline, at European level, only a small number of countries had adopted policies including HRDD legislation, inclusion of decent work clauses in trade agreements and IRBC agreements.

Fair Wear aims to conduct 700 L&A activities with different actors such as government officials, political leaders, media personnel, directly engaged brands (member brands of ETI or FW), indirectly engaged brands (not member brands of ETI or FW), TUs/ LRO and other actors towards improvement of labor rights.

title.narrative: Number of functional coalitions/networks/platforms in which STITCH participates

description.narrative: Coalitions are partnerships among distinct actors that coordinate action in pursuit of shared goals. Networks are forms of organization characterized by voluntary and reciprocal patterns of communication and exchange. Platform is a declaration of the principles on which a group of persons stands. This is a joint activity indicator (with contributions from multiple STITCH partners), and is only reported by this STITCH partner to avoid double counting

title.narrative: Human Rights Due Diligence by engaged brands drives improved purchasing practices that support and incentivise FoA, decent work and gender equality
Number of engaged brands which pay their share of the target (living) wage for > 75% of their production volume

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is checking if brand is paying its share of living wage for more than 75% of their production volume

comment.narrative: Not all Fair Wear and ETI member brands accept the need to change purchasing practices and FoA.
Fair Wear aims to contribute towards improvement of private sector company policies: 25 engaged brands pay their share of the target (living) wage for > 75% of their production volume

title.narrative: Number of engaged brands which mitigates root causes of excessive overtime

description.narrative: This indicator is specifically about one aspect of purchasing practices (excessive overtime) The numbers indicate that the brands are aware of excessive overtime in their sourcing factories and are taking measures to mitigate it

comment.narrative: Not all Fair Wear and ETI member brands accept the need to change purchasing practices and FoA.
Fair Wear aims to contribute towards improvement of private sector company policies: 50 engaged brands mitigates root causes of excessive overtime

title.narrative: Number of engaged brands which assesses and responds to root causes for wages that are lower than living wages in production locations

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is checking brand is aware that the wages offered by its suppliers is lower than living wage and takes action to correct this

title.narrative: Percentage of engaged brands which pay their share of the target (living) wage for > 75% of their production volume

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is reporting % of engaged brands that are paying their share of living wage for more than 75% of their production volume

title.narrative: Percentage of engaged brands which assesses and responds to root causes for wages that are lower than living wages in production locations

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is reporting on % of engaged brands where brand is aware that the wages offered by its suppliers is lower than living wage and takes action to correct this

title.narrative: Percentage of engaged brands which mitigates root causes of excessive overtime

description.narrative: This indicator is specifically about one aspect of purchasing practices (excessive overtime) The numbers indicate % of engaged brands that are aware of excessive overtime in their sourcing factories and are taking measures to mitigate it

title.narrative: Governments in production and EU buying countries create the opportunity to change and for inclusion of workers’ voices in negotiations and decision-making
Number of international agreements adapted /changed/blocked in favour of STITCH goals (contributable to the interventions of the program)

description.narrative: Number of unique international agreements adapted /changed/blocked in favour of STITCH goals (contributable to the lobby and advocacy interventions of the program) in each reporting period. This is a joint activity indicator (with contributions from multiple STITCH partners), and is only reported by this STITCH partner to avoid double counting

comment.narrative: The Agreement on Sustainable Clothing and Textile expires by end of 2021.
Includes negotiations for NL NGA (follow up of the Agreement on Sustainable Clothing and Textile)

This is a joint activity indicator (with contributions from multiple STITCH partners), and is only reported by this STITCH partner to avoid double counting

title.narrative: Private sector actors in the garment industry in production and EU buying countries accept the need to change purchasing practices and FoA
Percentage of total engaged brands actively promoting Freedom of Association

description.narrative: For ETI, the term ‘substantially improved Purchasing Practices’ means a member has made substantial changes made in line with ETI's guide to buying responsibly and also shared these actions/ changes publicly. For Fair Wear, the term ‘substantially improved Purchasing Practices’ means that the engaged brands have adopted front runner practices related to purchasing practices as documented in the brand performance check. These front runner practices are characterized by an achievement of 75% points scored on the Purchasing Practices section of the performance check.

title.narrative: Percentage of total engaged brands with substantially improved Purchasing Practices

description.narrative: For ETI, the term ‘substantially improved Purchasing Practices’ means a member has made substantial changes made in line with ETI's guide to buying responsibly and also shared these actions/ changes publicly. For Fair Wear, the term ‘substantially improved Purchasing Practices’ means that the engaged brands have adopted front runner practices related to purchasing practices as documented in the brand performance check. These front runner practices are characterized by an achievement of 75% points scored on the Purchasing Practices section of the performance check.

title.narrative: Number of total engaged brands actively promoting Freedom of Association

description.narrative: For ETI, the term ‘actively promoting FoA’ means that for this brand tha Principle of implementation 3.5 & 3.6 is in line with Implementing FoA - A 5 Step Plan. For Fair Wear, the term ‘actively promoting FOA’ means that the engaged brands have adopted front runner practices related to purchasing practices as documented in the brand performance check. These front runner practices are characterized by an achievement of 75% points scored on the Purchasing Practices section of the performance check.

title.narrative: Number of total engaged brands with substantially improved Purchasing Practices

description.narrative: For ETI, the term ‘substantially improved Purchasing Practices’ means a member has made substantial changes made in line with ETI's guide to buying responsibly and also shared these actions/ changes publicly. For Fair Wear, the term ‘substantially improved Purchasing Practices’ means that the engaged brands have adopted front runner practices related to purchasing practices as documented in the brand performance check. These front runner practices are characterized by an achievement of 75% points scored on the Purchasing Practices section of the performance check.

title.narrative: Reach
Total unique CSOs (not youth or women led) supported through capacity strengthening by STITCH

description.narrative: Neither women led nor youth led Labor right organizations that have received training from STITCH on one of the following topics: leadership skills, purchasing practices, social dialogue, sourcing dialogue, gender awareness, policy influencing lobby and advocacy, monitoring and evaluation or other topics. This is a joint activity indicator (with contributions from multiple STITCH partners), and is only reported by this STITCH partner to avoid double counting

comment.narrative: The L&A capacity of the CSOs will be assessed and capacity building on L&A will be provided as per needs. In all cases, STITCH tools/methodologies/research will be shared

Includes 6 first tier partners supported through capacity strengthening by STITCH. Over the course of the program, STITCH aims to share tools/methodologies/ research and provide training/ webinars/ learning sessions to partners on different topics such as Policy Influencing Lobby and Advocacy, leadership skills, purchasing practices, social dialogue, gender guidance etc.
6 first tier partners supported through capacity strengthening by STITCH

title.narrative: Total first tier CSO partners (not youth or women led) of STITCH

description.narrative: Includes first tier partners (neither women led nor youth led). This is a joint activity indicator (with contributions from multiple STITCH partners), and is only reported by this STITCH partner to avoid double counting

comment.narrative: the baseline values have been taken as 0, because even though STITCH members did partner with some of the first and second tier CSOs in their past projects, but new partnership contracts were drawn at start of STITCH program with all.

Includes CNV Internationaal (CNV-I), Mondiaal FNV, Center for Development and Integration (CDI) in Vietnam, Civil Initiatives for Development and Peace (Cividep) in India, British Ethical Trading Initiative (ETI) and Dutch Fair Wear Foundation (Fair Wear)
6 first tier partners of STITCH

title.narrative: Number of directly engaged brands supported by STITCH on apparel and garments sector

description.narrative: DDE Indicator. The indicator shows the total number of engaged brands supported by Fair Wear in the reporting periods. The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear.

title.narrative: Number of indirectly engaged brands supported by STITCH on apparel and garments sector

description.narrative: The term indirectly engaged brands refers to any garment brands who are not a member of ETI and Fair Wear, and the support provided to indirectly engaged brands includes sharing of STITCH tools/methodologies/ research through a webinar or training to these brands.

title.narrative: Conduct research to create evidence on labour conditions
Number of reports focused on labor conditions (e.g. studies, publication, position papers) conducted

description.narrative: Number of reports (e.g. studies, publication, position papers) focused on labour conditions conducted and published by the program

title.narrative: The voices of workers - and the trade unions representing them - and factories drive the implementation and prioritisation of brand action on Human Rights
Number of engaged brands for which information from worker driven information system is used to derive brand strategies/policies/ practices

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is checking whether brand action is backed by worker voice Assumption is: the brand has a system in place to collect worker voices, e.g. audits, HRDD application etc.

comment.narrative: The indicator will collect number of brands that will use HRDD system introduced by the project. At baseline the number of such brands was 0.
It is expected that numbers on this indicator will be reported upon once the HRDD system has been implemented in 2022.

title.narrative: Percentage of engaged brands with a system in place to collect and share worker driven information

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is checking % of engaged brands that have a system in place to collect worker voices, e.g. audits, HRDD application etc.

title.narrative: Percentage of engaged brands for which information from worker driven information system is used to derive brand strategies/policies/ practices

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is checking % of engaged brands, where brand action is backed by worker voice Assumption is: the brand has a system in place to collect worker voices, e.g. audits, HRDD application etc.

title.narrative: Number of engaged brands with a system in place to collect and share worker driven information

description.narrative:
The term (engaged) ‘brands’ is used for (directly engaged) garment companies (wholesale and retail) who are a member of Fair Wear or ETI.
Indicator is checking brand has a system in place to collect worker voices, e.g. audits, HRDD application etc.
